newsitem.title: MALAYSIA: Prime Utilities rating lowered to BBB2.
newsitem.headline: Prime Utilities rating lowered to BBB2.

text.p: The Rating Agency Malaysia (RAM) said on Monday it has downgraded sewerage treatment firm Prime Utilities Bhd's five-year bond issue to BBB2 from A3.

It said in a statement that Prime Utilities, which had been put under rating watch some time ago, was downgraded due to uncertainty over the company's earnings from its wholly-owned subsidiary Indah Water Konsortium, concessionnaire for the privatised sewerage services.
Prime Utilities issued the 60 million ringgit redeemable unsecured bonds last year.
It said various policy reviews by the government, due to which Indah had to write off 33 months of revenue before January 1, 1997, had affected its rating.
"Since the beginning of its operations on April 1, 1994, IWK has faced a spate of problems in collecting its bills," RAM said in the statement.
By October 31, 1996, IWK had only been able to collect 113 million ringgit of the 256 million billed to consumers.
IWK was acquired by Prime in November, 1995. IWK has a 28-year concession to manage the country's sewerage services.
In the current year, its first full year of billings, no data was yet available on bill collections, a key area of risk for Prime Utilities, RAM said.
After the write-off of revenues, the government has extended IWK's lease by 33 months and has also given it a soft loan of 450 million ringgit.
"Due to the substantial write-off of past revenue, it is certain that Prime Utilities will declare a substantial loss in financial year 1997," RAM said.
